channel.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India
channel.description: World News: TOI brings the latest world news headlines, Current International breaking news world wide. In depth analysis and top news headlines world wide.

image.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

item.title: 'Don't do something you might regret': UK PM's last request to voters ahead of general elections
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Ex-Pakistan PM Imran Khan's wife Bushra Bibi gets bail in graft case
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: UK court gives mixed ruling in Pfizer vs Moderna COVID vaccine patents case
item.description: London's High Court invalidated one of Moderna's COVID-19 vaccine technology patents, upheld another infringed by Pfizer and BioNTech's Comirnaty vaccine. Global legal battles continue as companies plan to appeal, ensuring vaccine production remains unaffected.

item.title: Fourth of July celebrations: Where to find the best fireworks in Los Angeles
item.description: As the fourth of July approaches, Los Angeles offers numerous prime locations to enjoy breathtaking fireworks. Popular spots include the Rose Bowl, Marina Del Rey, Disneyland, Hollywood Forever Cemetery, Long Beach, Huntington Beach, Universal Studios, and Hollywood Bowl. Each venue features unique celebrations, from soccer games and movie festivals to beach activities and patriotic-themed events, promising a spectacular Independence day experience.
item.dc:creator: TOI News Desk

item.title: Wickremesinghe responds to critics on Sri Lanka's debt restructuring deal
item.description: Sri Lankan President Wickremesinghe addresses criticism of debt restructuring, emphasizing transparency and parliamentary scrutiny. Details include debt total, interest rates, and sustainable debt focus. The plan aims to resume projects, secure foreign loans, and address short-term credit assistance. Opposition leader Premadasa questions the government's approach to debt restructuring.

item.title: At UN meeting, Taliban asked to include women into public life
item.dc:creator: TOI News Desk

item.title: New Zealand to press ahead with media content pay law
item.description: New Zealand's proposed bill to compel digital platforms to pay media for news faces opposition from the ACT New Zealand party, needing support from other parties to pass. The Labour party is expected to support the bill, aligning with the intent to help local media companies earn revenue.

item.title: Indian-American physician pleads guilty to $2.4 million healthcare fraud scheme
item.description: Indian American physician Mona Ghosh pleaded guilty to federal healthcare fraud for billing Medicaid and private insurers for non-existent services through her clinic, Progressive Women's Healthcare. Facing up to ten years per count in federal prison, Ghosh admitted responsibility for over $1.5 million in fraudulent reimbursements. Sentencing is scheduled for October 22, with prosecutors alleging she orchestrated a scheme involving false claims and overstated medical services from 2018 to 2022.
item.dc:creator: TOI News Desk

item.title: Indigenous ritual practiced for 12,000 years, study shows
item.description: For more than 10,000 years, people in a part of Australia practiced the same healing ritual. A new study has shown the ability of oral traditions to keep such practices alive across hundreds of generations. The discovery sheds light on the cultural practices of the Gunaikurnai people, and their healing rituals written down in the 19th century.

item.title: Hurricane Beryl, a Category 4 storm, pummels Caribbean islands, eyes Jamaica
item.description: Hurricane Beryl ripped off doors, windows and roofs in homes across the southeastern Caribbean on Monday after making landfall on the island of Carriacou as the earliest storm of Category 4 strength to form in the Atlantic, fueled by record warm waters. Beryl strengthened from a tropical depression to a major hurricane in just 42 hours — a feat accomplished only six other times in Atlantic hurricane history.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Jamie Foxx breaks silence on mysterious illness: 'I saw the tunnel'
item.description: Jamie Foxx's resilience and gratitude shine through as he navigates challenges, embracing life with renewed determination post-health scare. From 'In Living Color' to fatherhood, his journey underscores the preciousness of every moment, inspiring others to cherish life's opportunities with unwavering commitment and gratitude.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Why did the US judge call Karen Read’s cop boyfriend murder 'mistrial'?
item.description: Karen Read's murder trial ended in a mistrial after jurors deadlocked. The retrial will proceed, with prosecutors accusing Read of second-degree murder, manslaughter, and fleeing the scene. The case involves allegations of hitting her boyfriend with an SUV and a focus on police procedures during the investigation.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Australian firms given six months to develop code to prevent children from seeing porn
item.description: Australia has given the internet industry six months to create an enforceable code to protect children from online pornography and other harmful content or face government-imposed regulations. The eSafety Commissioner demands a plan by October 3, covering age verification, parental controls, and content filtering. Google and Meta pledged cooperation, while representatives from X and Apple have yet to comment.
item.dc:creator: TOI News Desk

item.title: 'Big win for constitution': Former US President Donald Trump hails Supreme Court's 'immunity' ruling
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: North Korea says its recent missile tests involved new ballistic missile with 'super-large warhead'
item.description: North Korea tested a new ballistic missile capable of carrying a warhead. These missile tests, including the Hwasongpho-11Da-4.5, signal readiness to counter US threats. The country has intensified weapon trials since 2022, targeting key nations and leveraging an expanded nuclear arsenal for future diplomacy. Monday's missile test was North Korea's first weapons firing in five days. Last Wednesday, North Korea launched what it called a multiwarhead missile in the first known test of a developmental weapon aimed at penetrating its rivals' missile defenses.

item.title: Hurricane Beryl razes southeast Caribbean as a record-breaking category 4 storm
item.description: Hurricane Beryl, the earliest Category 4 storm in the Atlantic, hit the southeastern Caribbean, causing severe damage but no immediate deaths. Winds reached 150 mph, affecting islands from St. Lucia to Grenada. Beryl is now moving toward Jamaica and Mexico's Yucatan peninsula. The storm's rapid intensification is attributed to record-warm waters, with officials warning of potential further damage.

item.title: Ahead of the election, Venezuela's Maduro says he has 'agreed' to resume negotiations with the United States
item.description: Venezuela's President Nicolas Maduro will resume negotiations with the US to lift economic sanctions ahead of a crucial presidential election. Facing his toughest challenge in decades, Maduro seeks a third term amidst a divided and diminished support base. Opposition candidate Edmundo Gonzalez Urrutia presents a significant threat to Maduro's re-election prospects.

item.title: Trump seeks to set aside New York hush money verdict hours after Supreme Court ruling
item.description: In prior court filings, Trump contended he is immune from prosecution for conduct alleged to involve official acts during his tenure in office. His lawyers did not raise that as a defense in the hush money case, but they argued that some evidence - including Trump's social media posts about former lawyer Michael Cohen - comes from his time as president and should have been excluded from the trial because of immunity protections.

item.title: Hawk Tuah girl offered $600 to spit in a jar: 'That's just disgusting'
item.description: Hawk Tuah girl Hailey Welch, in her first interview after her video went viral, said she does not want to be known as the Hawk Tuah girl. Now she has a team and a management and she thinks it was just a funny act and her parents too thought the same. Going forward, she would not want this to be her image and is planning to do shows and podcasts.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Melania Trump spotted outside Trump Tower, first time after skipping debate
item.description: ​All eyes are on Melania Trump as she is nowhere to be seen at Trump's campaign. She also missed the presidential debate. This was not the scene in 2016 and 2020. Reports claim Melania has made a deal with Trump that if he wins the presidency, she will not be the 24X7 first lady, She will be in the White House only on occasions -- and the rest of the time she will spend with their son Barron Trump who may join New York University in the fall.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk
